And also maybe the occasional wacky hijinks that seems to follow me around like some obsessive stalker, but that’s beside the point. Is this all I have to look forward to in life?”

1112.content:
You decided to steal the otter and prepared to defend yourself from the wolf-monkey. The creature slowly stalked toward you and bared its cruel fangs. You had no weapons, so you decided to create as much ruckus as possible in hopes of scaring the beast away. You unleashed the most terrifying growl in your repertoire, but the wolf-monkey only barked harsh laughter, and began to charge you. Thinking quickly, you reached behind you to the salt rock, scratched away small crystals with your fingernails, and flung them into the aberration's eyes. The family of otters watched in horror and fascination as the wolf-monkey howled in anguish, and ran off into the forest. The otters ran to their fallen companion, and reared up on their hind legs in an effort to keep you away from the body. However, your plan was never to use the dead otter for a snack, you were simply defending a nice creature that had helped you when you needed it. You told the otters to back down, and that you meant them no harm, and in a strangely human manner, they nodded, as if they understood your words, and crawled away with sullen gaits.
You carried the dead otter for hours until you found a spot you thought would be good to bury your fallen guide. The other otters still trailed, and you could feel their defeated spirit. You thought the otter that was killed may have been their father. With their help, you began to dig a small hole, and in a matter of minutes, a shallow grave was created. You gently placed the deceased otter inside, and listened to the chirps and growls of its family, singing their last words in a heartbreaking manner. You shoveled the dirt back over the body, and packed the earth with your bare feet. You turned around to see two of the otters carrying a beautiful green pine-cone, and they pressed the seed into the top of the loosened soil. "What is going on here?" you asked, "What was that thing? Where did it come from?"
The otters stood on their hind legs once more, lifted their little furry paws, and pointed behind you over the tree-line. You saw a large plume of unhealthy smoke, and heard a faint grinding of gears. You also heard the faint sound of human voices. You thanked the otters, and they scampered off, back into the water, and swam in the direction of the forest. One last otter was left behind, and it grabbed your leg, as if beckoning you to follow it.

11131.content:
Joseph scanned the ground and found something more impressive than a rock. Amongst the twigs, leaves, and brush there was a fairly thick, five foot long, white branch. He knelt down to examine it, gently caressing its rough surface with the tips of his fingers. Along its length, every few inches, he tested its strength by applying minor force to bend it. When at last he was satisfied with its strength, Joseph lifted his uncut spear and with the blunt end, he stabbed the ground as if posing for a painting.
The gralder cried out again. Joseph couldn’t tell if it was calling for help, begging for mercy, or just crying in pain. As Joseph approached for a closer look on the flailing yelping creature, he couldn’t help but pity the poor thing. Trying to get closer proved too hazardous as the thing slashed its claws at him. Even injured the damn thing’s dangerous, Joseph thought to himself. Well of course it is you moron. He rebuttled. Frightened animals are always dangerous. That’s why venomous snakes strike things they can’t eat.
Pulling himself back to reality, Joseph realized that the tree wasn’t that thick. And from what he could see, the gralder didn’t appear that injured. It could limp away and hunt otters until it healed. However, left in its current state it would probably attract all manner of predators looking for an easy meal. Joseph met eyes with the creature and marveled at its defiance against certain death.
It was decided. Joseph found a suitable rock and placed it beside the tree. Then, jamming the branch beneath the tree to use as a wedge, applied all his strength onto the branch, and finally forced the tree to move.
11131.title: Joseph Saves The Creature

1113111.content:
Joseph tensed as the animal took another step closer. “Back!” he yelled. She flinched at the sound of his voice, but otherwise didn’t react. She just kept winning their little staring contest game.
         At first she seemed to be offering the otter out of gratitude, or some manner of peace offering. If she had just dropped the damn thing and left, then things would have been fine and dandy. Joseph thought to himself. But no, the stupid beast had to take that extra step. They were in each other’s territory now; her within reach of his spear/club, and him within reach of her claws. She’s weak, injured. Even if she does attack, the best she can hope for is to knick me before I bash her brains out. What the hell could she be doing?
         Joseph got his answer as the gralder lowered her head and crouched submissively. If I didn’t know better, I’d think this bitch was offering herself to me. If this weren’t the first day I could remember, I’d have to say it was the weirdest day of my life. With his spear still trained on her head, Joseph pondered this for a few moments. Finally, he decided to do the only practical thing he could think of. Very slowly, Joseph lowered his spear, its tip descending from her forehead to her nose, her throat, chest, stomach, and at last falling upon the long dead otter.
         With a single motion he jabbed at the otter, piercing its flesh before jumping back, ready to fight off the gralder should this all have been some manner of trap. She hadn’t moved a muscle. Joseph took another step back then another. Once he had reached twelve foot distance, he decided that it was safe to turn his back. Almost immediately the gralder lifted its head from its submissive pose and started following him, limping the whole way. It didn’t take long for Joseph to notice. When he stopped she did as well. When he turned around she bowed her head.
         This game of stop and go continued for almost an hour before Joseph decided to take pity on the poor beast yet again. He slowed his pace significantly so that she didn’t have to hobble at top speed. He found another berry bush, eating his fill and then some, since he was unable to carry any with him. Then, looking at the dead otter still in his hand he confessed “I’m gonna make you into a berry pack.” Joseph walked far enough forward so that the gralder stood where he had squatted to eat the berries. He waited a moment to see if she would eat any. To his relief she did. At last the house was in sight. Still walking, Joseph decided it was time to name the gimpy beast. Turning his head to face her, he called out “Hurry it up Gimp. Or you’ll be late for supper.”
1113111.title: Gimp

11131111.content:
That evening, Joseph patrolled the area around the house, collecting as much fire wood as he could. He even found an impressively strong vine and a stick that looked like it would make a suitable splint. Another stick looked like it would make a good spit. He also found stones that would make excellent spark rocks. After he completed his foraging outside, he pointed at Gimp, telling her “Gimp. Stay.” Joseph then stepped inside to see if there was anything he could use that he had missed from this morning. To his great surprise, there was. At first figured that it would be fruitless to check the drawers a second time, but it was still a necessary precaution. But when the first drawer opened, he practically leapt for joy.
         Only a total of eight cabinets and drawers had opened across the house. This might have been disappointing, had it not been for the fact that almost everything he found was of use. Joseph’s new treasures included four boxes of matches, eighteen kitchen knives and two that could be useful in a fight, a bag full of various medicines, rags, towels, twelve spoons, two tool belts with holsters, a sewing kit, an ax, and much more. The final treasure he discovered was book containing detailed illustrations on the plants, creatures, and minerals of the forest. The title was Survival in Naxia.
         Once Joseph had come down from his present high, he remembered that he was hungry. The growls of his stomach grew ever louder as he began his work. He started by designating a spot for the fire by setting a circle of rocks and filling it with most of the dried wood he had collected earlier, with the exception of the pieces he had labeled the spit, splint, and the support for the spit which he set on either side of the fire pit. To Joseph’s immense pride, it only took him four tries with the spark rocks to start the fire. Following the fire, he bled the otter, followed by skinning it with one of the more peculiar shipped knives. Once the skin had been cleaned and the meat gutted, Joseph proceeded to jam the spit through the otter’s mouth and out the other end. With the mutilated corpse of a once living animal fully prepared and set atop the supports, the only thing left to do was wait.
         Gimp sat a few yards away from the fire, but with each gust wind she was reminded of the delicious smell of cooked meat and inched her way forward. Joseph noticed this and considered the ways he could hide the smell from any unwanted guests. Setting his spear on the ground next to him, Joseph picked up the book read to the fading light of the setting sun. Apparently the various occupants of Naxia were categorized according to their environment, diet, and level of intelligence. Before reading up on the goodies of Naxia, he decided to first look up its dangers. There were few venomous plants or animals and no threatening aquatic creatures. The chapter on the otters described them as adequately nutritious.
         The meat finally seemed ready. Placing the book down, Joseph grabbed one end of the spit and brought it to his mouth. “Delicious!” The book failed to describe how good they tasted. As Joseph finished off the last bit of flesh, he thought to himself that it could have use a tiny bit of salt, but that could be handled tomorrow. Joseph used the remaining meat to lure in Gimp so that she could be properly splintered. After wiping his hands on a towel, he poured dirt onto the fire, packed up his gear and made his way back inside, inviting the now splintered Gimp to follow. Joseph climbed into bed while Gimp curled up beside him and they both enjoyed a nice long sleep.

The problem was that they were clearly playing the quiet game, but Amethyst was cheating.

Amethyst’s eyes widened to the size of saucers when she saw the red woman. With the biggest breasts in the house, an ass that could deflect bullets, and thighs that once crushed a cannon ball, she was unquestionably the sexiest of the gems; at least now that Rose was ‘gone’. Her eyes were hidden behind her eye piece, but Amethyst could sense her silent, seething wrath. The purple woman tried motioning the unofficial leader to back away, but Garnet did just the opposite. She marched up to the bed and loomed menacingly for a few seconds. Then, just when Amethyst thought that things might be okay, the fusion reached out. Garnet slammed Steven all the way into Amethyst’s twat while simultaneously ripping off the zipper like a bandage.

“Fuuuck!” Amethyst cried out in a mix of bliss and pain. The sudden insertion pushed her over the edge, as it did Steven. She came hard and forcibly ejected the boy from his fleshy prison. He laid panting in a pool of sex juices between Amethyst’s legs as she looked up at the one responsible. “What was that for?”

“You know what you did,” Garnet said simply, her tone brokering no argument. She then picked up Steven and brought him up to her face. He groaned, clearly sore from his rough treatment, but he was a tough kid. He could take it. Besides, he smiled and waved when he saw the face of his tallest maternal figure. If she were organic and had a heart, this would be the part where it threatened to beat right out of her rib cage. But since that wasn’t the case, she opted to slide Steven into her mouth. He tasted lovely, as always, but she moved him into her cheek to get the final word in. “You’d better clean that up before Pearl sees.”

“B-but this was your fault,” Amethyst argued weakly. “You’re the one who made me cum so hard.”

“And you’re the one who forgot to set up a towel. As such, this was the most probable outcome.” Garnet adjusted her eye piece to indicate her future vision, forcing Amethyst to grumble her acceptance. “Good girl. Stay good, and I’ll talk to Pearl about giving you a treat.” She then left without elaborating further. According to her vision, Steven had quite the interesting day that he needed to start on.

Where does Steven go?
112321.title: A Day in the Life of Early Series Steven

choices: Steven heads back to the Temple
Steven hears something strange in the distance
Steven spots one of the gems in Beach City
1123213.content:
Garnet walked into the bathroom, which was unusual for her considering Gems don’t need to shower, wash up or do any other business in there. However, the boy curled up on her tongue did. Opening wide, she stared into the mirror, seeing the tiny naked young man straddled on top of her tongue, looking as happy as could be. He’d probably be happy if she just sucked on him all day and while she had done that before today wasn’t about having her little Steven candy to enjoy.

“Okay Steven, time to wash up. Saliva is great for getting cum off but you still need a shower,” Garnet said after plucking the boy up off her tongue and placing him in the bathtub. Instantly he was back to normal size and dripping wet, big globs of drool clinging to his face. While sticky Steven was okay around the temple, he couldn’t be walking around Beach City like this.

“Okay Garnet,” Steven said as he reached to turn on the water but paused as he remembered something. It was rude not to ask if someone wanted to join you. “Do you want to join me for a shower?”

Garnet tilted her head slightly. While gems didn’t need to take showers any reason to be naked around Steven was enjoyed. Garnet thought about it, using her ability to see where it would lead. “No thanks. I’ll just wait until later to put you up my butt.”

“Huh?” Steven said, not understanding what Garnet was referring to. If only he knew all the sexual outcomes that Garnet saw every day, he’d understand that her reddish complexion was probably there to hide her blushing cheeks from all the perverted things she witnessed. Leaving Steven alone, he shrugged and got on with his shower, scrubbing himself clean. He was a pro at this, the amount of stuff he found stuck to his body from his time having fun with the Crystal Gems was legendary. After he was finished, he dried off and left with a towel around his waist, couldn’t risk drawing one of the gems to him, and getting dirty all over again. Changing into a clean set of clothes he ran out of the temple, knowing exactly what he needed right now.

“One Big Mini Doughnut!”

Steven burst into the Big Doughnut crying out his order. He was hoping to see Sadie and Lars but he only saw the diminutive but sweet Sadie manning the cash register. She looked bored until she saw Steven come in, that always got a smile on her face. Rushing up to the counter, Steven slapped down one dollar for his favorite doughnut at the store, one that Sadie always saved for him no matter what.

“Hey Steven, great to see you. I got your mini doughnut right here,” Sadie said as she placed what looked like a third of a doughnut on the counter. It had started as an accident, one of the doughnuts broke apart and Lars threw it into the display because he didn’t care. Seeing the undersized, ignored piece that would be thrown away at the end of the day struck a chord in Steven’s heart and he had to save it and have it for himself. Since that day Sadie had always had a small mishappen piece for Steven.

“You’re the best, Sadie!” Steven truthfully said as he jumped up onto the counter, shrinking at the same time so when he landed, he was only three inches tall. The toy-sized boy scampered towards the now car-sized hunk of fried dough in delight.

“At least you think so. Lars has been complaining I’m too needy lately,” Sadie muttered not realizing she had said that out loud until she noticed Steven wasn’t eating his doughnut and instead was looking at her. Blushing, she quickly ducked her face down and tried to save her pride. “I mean, Lars has just been complaining I ask him too often to stay up all night… watching movies and playing video games.”

“What wrong with staying up all night. That sounds fun,” Steven said, missing the innuendo. Just because he knew more about how to pleasure a pussy than most men alive didn’t mean he understood when people were trying to be coy about what they were saying. “I can come next time and all three of us could stay up all night,” Steven quickly suggested. He was trying to be helpful, but he didn’t know what he was talking about. To be fair, if he did understand he’d still volunteer to join in.

“I don’t think Lars would like that,” Sadie said, not saying that she would have a problem. The way she was blushing even harder and biting her lip, she probably was more than okay with both of the boys spending all night with her. Shaking that thought out of her head, Sadie just sighed and turned away. This was really not Steven’s problem and she shouldn’t be bothering him with it. She remembered the last time she dragged Steven into her problems with Lars and her own needs. What happened then could never happen again.

“Are you sure there isn’t anything I can do?” Steven asked, honestly trying to help. Sadie looked at his big warm smile and his tiny adorable form and just felt her heart melt. She remembered last time all too well. She had felt so lonely and had gone on an early break to feel better, expecting Lars to watch everything. He had bailed, of course, and Steven wandered in and found her in the back, panties around her ankles and fingers about to go into herself. She barely remembers what happened next, only Steven offering to help, the most incredible pleasure, and then guilt. She had tried so hard to forget it, but it was hard with Steven always being there for her at her lowest. If he was just older or she was younger things would be so very different and she wouldn’t feel like the worst person ever.

“I just need to take a break. I’ll be back in a couple of minutes,” Sadie excused herself, leaving Steven to finish his tiny treat. Steven watched her go sadly, but he knew when someone wanted to be alone. Taking a few more bites of his doughnut, he decided to leave. Regrowing himself he left the Big Doughnut in search of something else to do.
1123213.title: Doughnut Break

114.content: In the strange and magical world of Oo, there are all sorts of possibilities for some sexy fun. Now, how to start. Should the characters try experimenting with eating one another, or maybe one or more of the numerous ladies try fooling around with their lady parts? Maybe there's some funky size changing bizz going on? Or maybe things get all donked up and random?
114.title: Adventure Time

1141.content:
“I remember I had first awoken in, of all things a bed. A nice comfortable bed with 3 layers of blankets, 2 pillows, and a quilt on top.” He did his best to recount as much detail as possible to keep the story going. “Right away I knew that I had no idea where I was or who I was, so I pulled myself up. Once I saw that I wasn’t wearing anything, I tried to cover myself up, but after a couple minutes of listening to the singing birds outside, I figured that there wasn’t anyone around to see me. I knew that the first thing I needed was to get my bearings, so I surveyed the room for anything of interest.
         “All in all, there was a dresser, three large empty book stands, a chair, desk, and two windows with their blinds shut. There are still a few contraptions in there that I haven’t quite figured out yet. Maybe when you get better you could give them a look-see.” Felecia drifted in and out of consciousness, but Joseph knew he could keep her with him with the sound of a familiar voice.
         “I noticed that there was some kind of switch on the wall to my left. I gave it a flip, but nothing happened. There were three doors, but only one was open. I got up to test the closed doors, but they were all locked. After trying the dresser and a few other cabinets around the room, I started thinking that maybe everything closed was also locked. Once I had finished a brief expedition of the hall way, living room and kitchen, I found that my theory was correct in every regard except one.
         “The only other open door was to the forest. Looking through the glass windows, the word ‘backyard’ came to mind. Not sure why but it seemed appropriate. Despite sunlight shining through the blinds in all other windows, the backyard was surprisingly dark. I guess it’s due to the thickness of the canopy. Anyway, since I had nothing better to do indoors, and a warm refreshing breeze was blowing in through a partially opened window, I figured I might as well go outside and enjoy the day.
         “After about fifty feet of what some might consider stalking, probably not you, I decided to look back at the place where I had woken. The house itself seemed fairly normal, but the really freaky thing was directly on top. An enormous metal wall with some kind of glowing array of opaque lights shooting out above it seemed to run right through the house. Seriously though, part of that damn Fence makes up a huge barren dead end of a wall. I swear it’s like we’re cut off from the other end of the house. But I digress, the Fence stretched out endlessly in either direction; or at least it would have if all the trees hadn’t blocked my view.
         “Remember when you told me about the Fence?” Joseph inquired while he set various items beside his patient as per the directions in the book. When Felecia didn’t answer, Joseph just continued talking. “Your right. I guess it’s not really relevant to this part of the story anyway. You don’t come in until much later. I’m just letting you know that I haven’t forgotten you."
1141.title: Flashback

11411.content:
“I had walked along the edge of the Fence for almost two hours with nothing really catching my eye. The only thing to grab my attention was throat becoming quite dry. Finally I found myself some water at Gigigly. We’ll get into how that place is relevant a bit later. Anyway, the Fence ran straight through clear sparkly pond. Regardless of whatever you might think, I am not now, nor was I ever completely devoid of common sense. I found a long stick and proceeded to poke into the water. I wasn’t just testing the depth; I was also making sure that there wasn’t anything lurking beneath the surface. Once I found a sufficiently shallow pool, I dipped my hands in for several refreshing gulps.
         “When a splash came from out in the pond, it made me jump back and fall on my butt.” Joseph smiled to himself as he watched her eyes move beneath their lids, “You know, if you were awake right now you’d be laughing too. Anyway, I scanned the surface of the water for any signs of movement. About half way across the lake, were four small heads poking out of the water and swimming towards land. I hid behind a tree until I saw that the creatures crawling out of the pond were some kind of green otters. They were really small, so I saw no harm in stalking them for a bit.
         “I figured if critters that small were moving around in broad daylight, then surely it meant that there were no predators to worry about. It would be nice to bathe in the pond without any worries of being torn in half. With the stick still in hand, I followed the otters for most of the day.
         “You know,” Joseph began as he filled a syringe with a pink liquid “following a gaggle of otters through a forest, buck naked for several hours sounds pretty exciting. But after a while, I gave the otters a silent “thank you.” After all, they had taught me so much about the place I now call home. I got to see which berries were safe to eat. I saw some weird ants that apparently like fecal matter. At which I thought: Nice. Now I don’t have to worry about stepping in anyone’s crap, especially my own. I even saw a boar carcass, which was a lot more interesting than it sounds. Based on its flat teeth, I managed to deduce that I could hunt them if I managed to get a better stick. Don’t get me wrong, but those things are pretty damn big. No offense.”
         As Joseph injected the pink liquid into Felecia’s forearm, he couldn’t help but marvel at his own skills. It was as if his hands instinctively knew what to do, and were operating independent of his own mind. He had the hands of a forty year medical veteran even though stubble was just beginning to grow on his chin.
         “Anyway, the remaining discoveries of the day included a patch of plants that the otters dug up. I gave em a try and they weren’t too bad. There was also a rock that they licked. I used my finger to give it a taste. It had this really weird flavor. It was nowhere near as weird as what went on in my head. A moment after the stuff had dissolved in my mouth, I thought the word: salt. A flood of images then poured into my head, showing me things like how I could grind up the salt rocks and use them to preserve dead animals for later use. It was easily the trippiest moment of the day.”
         Taking a moment to catch his breath, Joseph followed the next few steps in the medicine book. He grabbed two small rags. The first he folded and maneuvered into her mouth. The second he soaked in alcohol.
         “I might have kept on following those cute little guys were it not for what happened next. A solitary predator about half the size of the pig, jumped out of the bushes, grabbed an otter and snapped its neck all in the blink of an eye. It had kind of a wolf’s head, monkey’s body, long arms with long claws, and fairly sharp teeth. As I sat there and watched the thing fling the corpse around, giving little roars of victory, I wondered what to do next. Should I avoid it and not make any enemies, or steal the dead otter for myself?
         “By the way, I take no enjoyment in this whatsoever.” Joseph concluded his speech as he gently placed the alcohol drenched rag against her wound. Felecia’s eyes flew open, her screams muffled under the rag. Upon seeing such a powerful creature reduced to relying on his care, Joseph gave a quick snicker before continuing.
11411.title: Out For A Stroll

114111.content:
Felecia’s eye lids quivered a bit before opening. As her body slowly began to relax, her half closed eyes wandered the room before falling on Joseph. Upon seeing Joseph’s face, she was greeted with a relieved smile. “Hey there sleepy head. Welcome back to the world of the living.”
         Felecia moaned groggily and made muffled sounds through the rag that sounded vaguely like “Where are we?” Her voice was deep and almost sensual. Taking into account the rag in her mouth and her severe loss of blood, her voice might as well have been a whisper compared to her usual volume.
         Continuing to apply pressure against the rag on her side, Joseph asked “We’re in my house. Are you feeling any better?”
         Using her left and severely less bruised arm Felecia removed the cloth from her mouth. “There’s less pain, but my head’s all fuzzy. Why am I here?”
         Joseph grabbed her right hand and placed it over the cloth on her wound, telling her to keep up the pressure while he got something out of a med-kit. “You were attacked, remember? You said that you were ambushed on patrol so you came here looking like that. I managed to walk you to this room and started working on your injuries. We’ll be talking about how you look later.”
         “Thank you” Felecia wheezed as she rested her eyes.
         “Yeah, cause right now we got more pressing issues. Tops on the list: won’t they be able to track you here? Why didn’t you go back to your cave?”
         Doing her best to formulate words despite her loss of blood, Felecia did her best to answer his questions. “My cave was too far from where they ambushed me. Even if it wasn’t, it’s not the most defendable of positions, especially in my present state.” Felecia hissed as Joseph applied medicine soaked cotton balls against her various scratches. “Besides, this is the most secure place I know of.”
         “Are you fucking kidding me?” he asked, extending his arm in the direction of the living room. “We’ve got a wall that’s made up of mostly glass. I don’t know if you’ve heard but glass is pretty flimsy.”
         Felecia gave a light chuckle. “This place may have the look and feel of wood, glass, and carpet, but trust me when I say that this place is impenetrable.”
         “Are you sure?”
         Lifting her eyelids slightly to see Joseph’s stress, Felecia answered “I nearly dislocated my shoulder trying to smash through that ‘flimsy’ glass not three months before you appeared. It’s likely that nothing short of a falling tree is capable of breaking through these walls.”
         “Well…ok” Joseph said. Felecia’s calmness even in the face of certain death was most reassuring. “If you’re sure there’s no way for them to get in.”
         “The only way I know of is through the locked door.”
         Joseph’s eyes widened as he faced away from Felecia.
         “You did lock the door, didn’t you?”
114111.title: She Wakes

1141111.content:
“Why don’t I just go and check.” Joseph said as he rose to his feet, collecting his spear and knife, and walked towards the hallway. Looking back he instructed “just keep putting pressure on that cloth and you should be alright.”
         As he walked out the archway to the room where the weakened Felecia still lay, Joseph began going over the configuration of the house in his mind. To his right was the room where he use to sleep. He gave a quick peek inside. Satisfied that there were no predators small enough to hide in there he turned his attention to the left. After seeing no immediate danger, Joseph made his way down the hall. At the other end of the hall was the living room and the only door in and out of the house. Between him and the door rested a large couch and two recliners. They would provide decent cover to approach the door unnoticed.
         The problem lay in uncertainty; the uncertainty as to whether or not the door was already locked, and the uncertainty about the condition of the blinds. Normally Joseph left the blinds open during the day to help warm the house. As per Felecia’s advice, he started closing the blinds at night to keep his privacy. It was a new habit that had yet to completely sink in.
         Finally coming to the end of the hall, Joseph knew his next step would be to peek around the corner to check on the blinds and the door. If the blinds for the window wall were closed then he could probably head straight for the door without pause. Open blinds would call for a much more subtle approach, especially if there was movement outside. However, the biggest issue wasn’t whether or not the door was locked, but whether or not it was closed. Even if it wasn’t locked the only way to open it was to turn the handle and the only predators in Naxia with opposable thumbs were him and apparently Felecia. If he hadn’t closed the door completely and it had been blown open by a gust of wind, then something may have already wandered in. something that Joseph wasn’t confident he could take with just a spear and knife.
         The moment of truth.
1141111.title: Checking The Door

11411111.content:
“Damn” Joseph muttered to himself. In this poor light, the door seemed as closed as it could get, but the blinds were open.
         “Can’t move fast” Joseph muttered to himself as he ducked down, ready to jump behind the couch. “Gotta be cautious.” The storm continued to rage outside. The songs of nocturnal birds drowned out by the constant thud of raindrops and the occasional boom of thunder. The dangerous part was the lightening. If he peeked out during a flash then he might be able to see outside movement, but if anything was out there they’d certainly be able to see him, flash or no flash.
         Staying as low as possible, Joseph tucked and almost rolled behind the couch. Still in crouching position he moved swiftly behind the couch. Arriving at the edge, weapons still in hand, Joseph made another jump, this time for the first recliner. As he did so a flash of light filled the room. While taking a moment to catch his breath, Joseph felt the rumble of thunder move through his entire body, accompanied, shortly after, by distant howls.
         With each breath, Joseph’s heart seemed to beat faster. At this point he was actually to the right of the door. Directly in front of him was the brick and wood part of the wall. He continued to hide behind the recliners until he was completely against the wall. Pressing himself against it, Joseph made good time to the door. Confirming that it was indeed unlocked, he considered the next challenge.
         Joseph still didn’t know whether or not the predators were near yet, the door was half made of glass, and the door-knob. He would have to reach out across almost two feet of transparent glass, provoking anything within twenty meters to charge.
         Fearing that the sound of his racing heart could be heard over the sound of the storm, Joseph attempted to calm himself. “They’re just dumb animals you moron. Even if they do see you they don’t know how doors work.” Starting to laugh a bit, Joseph continued muttering to himself. “Besides, if the door’s closed enough to endure the wind then it could probably take a direct hit from a charging rhino. Right?”
         Making up his mind, Joseph discarded the notion of reaching slowly across the door. Instead he dropped his weapons and made one last jump in front of the door, turning the lock until he heard the click.
         As he stared outside, the constant splatter of drops continuing to bombard its glass, Joseph felt a wave of relief wash over him. Bursts of laughter were interrupted by brief but deep calming breaths. All was right in the world as lightning flashed again, illuminating the swaying brush outside and covering it in an instant with a mass of fur and teeth.
11411111.title: Closed Door, Open Blinds

114111111.content:
Positioned not ten inches from the door was the nose of a Drom. The giant wolf’s body and face was covered in long black fur, a pair of horns as thick and long as a human arm protrude threateningly from its head and eyes, as bright and yellow as the sun, glared level with Joseph’s. The monster’s long fangs had such strength and sharpness that they made Joseph’s spear the equivalent of a tooth-pick. This thought provoked a most unpleasant image in Joseph’s mind.
         The latest resident of Naxia might have gone on to examine other intimidating features of this vicious beast; he might even have noticed an entire pack pacing back and forth just behind it. However, Joseph was far too preoccupied with the rows of flesh rending teeth that were revealed by the drom’s partially opened mouth. There were also the drom’s eyes to consider; those deep golden eyes that seemed to consume all those who lost their way in them.
         Out of nowhere the beast moved, opening its mouth several inches before closing to its original position, almost like a silent bark. A startled Joseph took several steps backward. The scare tactic had effectively broken him out of thed trance. Able to think again, Joseph started remembering Felecia’s teachings. The first was in regards to large predators and how to never look them in the eye. After that, the dam in his mind collapsed and al his lessons came rushing back.
         Joseph recounted one of Felecia’s earliest lessons. He remembered the way she would stare out across the forest as she lay sunning on one of the large rocks outside her cave, her cat like tail swaying from side to side. A gust of wind brought with it a flurry of pollen, causing Joseph periodic sneezes.
         Without even glancing at him, she said “Show no fear. It is the defining feature of prey when they are afraid; especially in the minds of the scavengers. To show fear is to admit weakness to a harsh and unforgiving world. A beast may not have fang, claw, or horn to boast of, but if they are not afraid then they likely have just reason to be so. Be it out of ignorance or confidence, it is a dangerous gamble to charge the one who is not afraid.” It was then that Felecia turned her head and looked him straight in the eye. “Prove yourself and do not blink” she said as she continued staring right through him. “Show no fear. Show no weakness.”
         Joseph had failed the first test, but after weeks of practice all his hard work seemed to have paid off. Just as Felecia told him, Joseph stood his ground, choosing to stare between the beast’s eyes rather than into them. He crunched his brow, tensed his muscles threateningly, and bore his teeth with a low growl.
         The drom attempted another bark, this one less silent. It took every ounce of Joseph’s will power not to budge as he stared past the razor sharp teeth into the gaping maw that could swallow him whole. The beast stared into Joseph’s eyes in an effort to lock him in another trance, but to no avail. It could find no fear to latch on to, only courage. Slowly it began to dawn on the drom that perhaps the naked pink creature it stared at wasn’t prey. No prey could stare into his eyes without shaking in fear. The over-fluffed puppy lowered its gaze as he cautiously backed away.
         Satisfied that both he and Felecia were safe, and that he had stood his ground, Joseph started to move again. Without ceasing to stare through the glass, Joseph collected his weapons, confirmed one last time that the door was locked and proceeded to close the blinds. With everything set and secure, Joseph used the remains of his strength to move himself out of the living room and into the hallway. There he collapsed, tears of fear flowing from his eyes. Joseph remained this way for several minutes.
114111111.title: Show No Fear

1141111111.content:
Once he was content that he had recovered enough to move and all the tears had drained away, Joseph made his way back to the room of his patient, leaving his weapons back in the hall. As he fell to his knees by her side, Felecia looked up into his red watery eyes. Without needing to ask why, she reached out and touched Joseph’s knee. “Nice job kid.” Felecia said proudly, giving him the necessary strength he needed to continue.
         Wiping away the remains of his tears, Joseph smiled back at Felecia. “Right. Well, I hate to leave things unfinished, so why don’t I pick up where we left off.”
         “Wonderful” Felecia said rolling her eyes and pulling her hand back.
         Trying to remember where he had last stopped, Joseph dived back into his tale. “Um, this next part’s a bit fuzzy, but I’ll do my best.” Joseph said hesitantly. “As I weighed my options I noticed some mysterious crackling sound that seemed to reverberate throughout the woods. It grew louder and louder until it sounded like thunder, and I watched as one of the trees started to fall. It wasn’t falling towards me and that was good, especially since I was so freaked that I couldn’t move. The creature I was watching seemed to be in the same boat. The only difference was that the tree fell on her instead of me.
         “This part is also a bit fuzzy. All I can really remember is this unbearable stabbing headache. I pressed my hands against my head for all the good it did me. The only other thing I remember before passing out was some kind of flash inside my mind; so many lights and shapes.” Joseph had to look away for a moment. Every time he thought about his headaches, he seemed to cause them to come back.
         “When I finally came to, I saw that the creature was writhing underneath the tree. I looked at her and immediately the word ‘Gralder’ came to mind.” Joseph smiled exhaustively and shook his head. “I started wondering how I suddenly knew what the gralder’s name was when I hadn’t a clue only a couple minutes ago. The only thing that really came to mind was that flash in my head. Thankfully before I could put in any serious thought and cause a relapse, the gralder decided to cry out and snap me back to my senses. I walked over to the squirming monkey-thing and noticed he saw that she had dropped the otter a few feet away. As I got closer, I met eyes with her and she stopped struggling. I can’t really explain it, but I think we share a little moment of understanding. The gralder’s back leg was being crushed beneath the tree and there was no way for her to escape. She was fully aware that I could find a large rock, smash her skull, and eat the remains.
1141111111.title: Where Was I?

11411111111.content:
“Don’t ask me why, but somehow I knew that I couldn’t just kill her. And to make a long story short I broke off a thick branch from the fallen tree and used it as a lever to move the tree just enough for the gralder to escape. All the while a voice in the back of my head kept screaming at me, calling me an idiot. So you see, I really don’t need your help in that regard.
         “Once she was free, I immediately took several steps back. She rose to her maximum height and started stretching her various extremities. For some reason she felt the need to start doing a little dance, it was like she was celebrating her survival. Eventually she decided to test her leg. She put her weight on it for barely an instant before immediately pulling her broken leg back into the air. She gave a light yelp.
         “I think I must have laughed or something, cause then the gralder looked at me. Her face was blank as her eyes seemed to survey me. I watched her eyes dart between me and the tree branch that I held between us. I guess she was confused at the fact that she was still alive, and more so that I had spared her. She turned away from me and buried her face in the brush on the ground, sniffing through the twigs until she found her way to where the otter had dropped. She picked it up with her jaws and turned back to face the naked beast with the large stick.” Joseph’s eyes darted to Felecia’s face. He could have sworn that she had just smiled, if only for a second. Joseph continued telling his story, confident that his words were indeed getting through to her.
         “With seemingly intelligent and humble movements, and the otter still in her mouth, the gralder started moving closer and closer to me. Guessing her intentions, I lowered my stick a bit as a sign of good will. But I never stopped aiming the sharp end at her. If it was a trick, I wasn’t going to fall for it. She continued to approach until she was mere inches outside of my stick’s range. She opened her mouth a bit and let the otter drop from her lips and hit the ground with a light thud.
         “It could have ended there, but it didn’t. I had almost completely relaxed my stick and everything. I was even in the process of pulling it out of its threatening position. That’s when the gralder did something to make us both very nervous. She took another step forward.
11411111111.title: Peace Offering

114111111111.content:
“I gotta tell ya, I was tense as hell. I even yelled ‘Back’!” Joseph raised his voice a bit to try and match his original volume. “She flinched a bit at the sound of my voice, but otherwise didn’t react. She just kept taking baby step after baby step.
         “I thought to myself: If she had just dropped the damn thing and left, then things would have been fine and dandy. But no, the stupid beast had to take that extra step. We were in each other’s territory then; her within reach of my spear, and me within reach of her claws. She’s weak, injured, I said to myself. Even if she does attack, the best she can hope for is to knick me before I bash her brains out. What the hell could she be doing?
         “I got my answer when the gralder lowered her head and crouched submissively. If I didn’t know better, I thought, I’d think this bitch was offering herself to me. If that weren’t the first day I could remember, I’d have to say it was the weirdest day of my life. With my spear still trained on her head, I pondered this for a few moments. Finally, I decided on the only practical option available. Very slowly, I lowered my spear past her until it was pointing at the dead otter.
         “With a single motion I jabbed at the otter, piercing its flesh before jumping back. I was ready to fight off the gralder if it had turned out to have been some manner of trap. She hadn’t moved a muscle. I kept moving back until I was about four meters away, and decided that it was safe to turn my back. The instant I did so the gralder lifted its head from its submissive pose and started following me. She limped the whole way.
         “It was pretty weird. When I stopped she did as well. When I turned around she bowed her head. We played this game of stop and go for almost an hour before I decided to take pity on the poor beast yet again. I slowed my pace significantly so that she didn’t have to hobble at top speed. I found another berry bush and ate my fill since there was no way to carry any with me. I even let the gralder eat her fill after I had walked far enough forward. It was kind of relieving to see her eat. Once the house was finally in sight, I decided it was time to name the gimpy beast. Turning around to face her, I called ‘Hurry it up Gimp. Or you’ll be late for supper’.”
114111111111.title: Meeting Gimp

1141111111111.content:
“That evening, I patrolled the area around the house, collecting as much fire wood as I could. I even found some material that looked like it would make a suitable splint for Gimp. I also found stones that made excellent spark rocks. Once I was done foraging outside, I told Gimp to stay put while I ventured inside to find anything of use that I might have missed earlier. Surprisingly, there was plenty.
         “Only a fraction of the cabinets and drawers had opened around the house. This might have been disappointing, had it not been for the fact that almost everything I found was of use. My new treasures included four boxes of matches, kitchen knives, two of which looked like they could be useful in a fight, rags, towels, silverware, two tool belts with holsters, a sewing kit, an ax, a small case full of various medicines and bandages, and much more. My final treasure that day was book containing detailed illustrations on the plants, creatures, and minerals of the forest. The title was Survival in Naxia.” Pausing for a bit, “Yes I know, we’ll be getting to the book in a bit.
         “I finally remembered that I was hungry. The growls in my stomach were growing ever louder as I began my work. I started by designating a spot for the fire, setting the rocks in a circle, filling it with most of the dried wood I had collected earlier, and set the other pieces in their respective locations. It only took me about four tries with the spark rocks to start the fire; I was so proud. Then I bled, skinned, cleaned, gutted, and finally roasted the otter. With the mutilated corpse of a once living animal fully prepared and set atop the supports, the only thing left to do was wait.
         “With Gimp sitting a few yards away from the fire, and my spear resting next to him, I picked up the book and read to the fading light of the setting sun. It was a very detailed book; with its categorizations and big words that I still don’t fully understand. Apparently the various occupants of Naxia are categorized according to their environment, diet, and level of intelligence. I didn’t make it very far that night, but I did skim through some of the edible and poisonous plants.
         “Once the meat seemed ready, I put the book down, grabbed one end of the spit and took a big bite.” Joseph paused for a moment as he recounted that first bite. “It was freaking delicious. After I had my fill I used the remaining meat to lure in Gimp so that she could be properly splintered. After putting out the fire I packed up the gear and made my way back inside, inviting the now splintered Gimp to follow. I climbed into the old bed while Gimp curled up beside me and we both drifted off to sleep.”
1141111111111.title: Make It Home

11411111111111.content:
“That morning I had practically leapt out of bed. It didn’t matter that the bright light of the new morning was upon my face, that damn shine nearly had burned his eyes out. My eyes adjusted soon enough. The drumbeat of my heart overwhelmed the songs of birds which had greeted me the previous day. I tried to recount exactly what had scared me so much; what my nightmare had been about.” Joseph began to shutter. It was like standing in front of that damn Drom all over again. Joseph was always a bit shaky when it came to thinking about sleep and dreams. “But as with most dreams, it quickly escaped me.
         “I felt a sudden pressure around my arm and jerked, only to see that it was a concerned Gimp. I guess she had sensed my terror and had attempted to wake me up. Gods I hate to think about if she failed.
         “Once I had succeeded in reassuring both her and myself I tried to wipe the sleep from my eyes. Once my fingers came to a rest upon my lips, I noticed something was wrong with my face. I brought up my other hand and touched all parts of my mouth.” Joseph brought up his hands exactly as he had described and touched his mouth. The corners were far apart and my teeth were exposed.” Joseph hesitated before declaring, “I was smiling.”
         Joseph chuckled to himself as he continued. “I was smiling. I don’t know how but somehow I knew that it was related to my dream. Having been left in such an uncertain and terrifying position, even more so than yesterday, I reacted the only way he could. I laughed.
         Joseph took a deep breath to prevent his eyes from watering. “I was genuinely amused by my predicament. The full impact of everything hit me like a ton of bricks. It wasn’t that I was clueless about my current situation or the content of my dream. My amusement and laughter came from a gut feeling I had. A gut feeling that told me that I’d likely spend every night this way for the rest of my life.”
11411111111111.title: The Nightmare

114111111111111.content:
Joseph paused for a moment, wondering how to continue while avoiding the more difficult speech topics. “Actually, I think I’m gonna skip the next three months of the story and get right to the good parts.”
         “Oh thank you Joseph.” She said sarcastically with a forced grin. “Oh thank you, thank you. And once again, thank you.”
         “Right. Now let’s try and set the mood. The smell of fresh rain and blooming flowers permeated the air. Chirping insects, singing birds, and the occasional howl in the distance, gave the forest an overwhelming and almost soothing thrum. I could hardly keep his eyes open as I sat up against the red tree. I sat beneath an exceptionally large hole in the canopy, enjoying the feel of the warm sun against my wet skin. I had just finished a nice swim in the pond.
         “Even the rumble of a nearby snoring Gimp was lulling me to sleep. She had been so relieved at having her cast removed that she wore herself out in celebration.” Joseph smiled as he recounted how the fuzzy creature had galloped and bounded around the pond while he swam.
         “I was on the verge of taking a nap, but I managed to pull myself out of it.” Joseph shuddered. “I had kinda made a commitment to sleep only as much as my body needed and not a second more. I looked around to find something to keep my mind occupied.
         “A newly carved and hardened spear lay by my side. It seemed to be waiting impatiently for the next hunt when it would again taste blood.” Joseph smiled as he noticed the empathy in Felecia’s expression. “Hanging from a nail directly overhead was my old pack holding a few pieces of red fruit, the guide book, a cutting knife, about 20ft of poorly crafted rope if I do say so myself, and a pair of trunks I had made from that first pig. I could have taken the trunks swimming with me, but they itched something awful. So they were left hanging while I got my bare ass dirty again.
         “It was about that time that I thought of the book. I extracted it from the pack, opening up to the page I had marked with a strand of long grass.”
114111111111111.title: A Day of Peace

1141111111111111.content:
“The freaking book again?” Felecia asked. “I thought you were gonna start on the good parts.”
         “Just shutup and listen” Joseph contended. “If it makes you feel better I could just put you out of your misery now, or maybe I should find a blunt object, knock you out and continue past the part I know you’re looking forward to.” Joseph smiled as he spoke those last few words. He knew that he had power over her, at least in this particular situation, and he was going to milk it for all it was worth. Felecia averted her eyes, signaling that he had permission to go on.
         “So. As I flipped through the pages of my personal bible, I recounted what a marvelous and useful tool it was. It had taught me what I could and couldn’t eat, which things were poisonous, some crap about fertile soil, and a lot more stuff that even you can’t tell me. The opening two pages held a detailed fold out map of all Naxia. As you might have already known, this land was shaped like a perfect square. I was able to make out where my house was in relation to trails, bodies of water and a suspicious labyrinth of stone in a place called Naxia’s Teeth.
         “The bulk of the book seemed more like one giant glossary than a guide. It was divided into several volumes. Each detailed the different species in Naxia.
         “However, amidst sea of words of the first few Volumes, I discovered some highly unusual marks. While the majority of the book was quite readable, every now and then a string of unfamiliar symbols would replace words, sentences, and even whole paragraphs. At first I didn’t think much of it cuz I was still shocked that I could even read. But these marks really got my attention when I noticed a substantial increase within the chapter on deadly diseases.”
         “You shouldn’t let it bother you too much” Felecia comforted. “I’ve read that book and I’ve seen those grey areas. Trust me that I can fill in most of those gaps through life experiences. After all, I’ve been here a lot longer than you.”
         “Yes” answered Joseph sarcastically. “The almighty Felecia rushes in yet again to save the day. Anyway, Volumes Three and Four described the fungus and plants of the forest. I skimmed through this section rather quickly, so the only things to catch my attention were a picture of a patch of long grass with a large rock resting behind its rows and an orange moss with the ability to decompose fecal matter. If I’m using too many big words, it means that you can crap on it one day and come back the next to find a bigger clump of moss.” Joseph laughed to himself as he remembered the first time he read this and how he had found a patch of moss near his house and tested it.
1141111111111111.title: Read The Book

choices: Reptiles and Birds and Mammals. Oh My! (Reserved)
11411111111111111.content:
“Volume Five, while being only slightly longer than its predecessors, held the most interest for me. It was about the various animal species that seemed to be in every nook and cranny of the forest.
         “After the insects of Section One, Section Two depicted a rather pleasant series of fairly harmless and colorful amphibians, with the exception of a few rainbow frogs. While they had neither teeth nor venom, they secreted hallucinogenic mucus from their skin when frightened. A quote from the author directly following this fact still confuses me. ‘Don’t even think about it.’ Weird huh?” Felecia chuckled to herself, gaining Joseph’s attention. “Is there something you’re not telling me?”
         Felecia shook her head. “Of course there is. A woman has to have her secrets after all.”
         “We’re talking about hallucinogenic frogs here” Joseph retorted with a puzzled expression. “I’m pretty sure that has nothing to do with a woman’s secrets.”
         “I know what it means. Just do what the damn book says and try not to think about it.” Felecia waited a moment while Joseph attempted to stare her down. She half-smiled at his newfound boldness. Rather than do the same back to him, she merely gave him a look that said that she could but chose not to. Staring into her deep golden slit eyes, Joseph was the first to back down. “Just don’t go sticking the damn things in your mouth without cooking them first. You’ll live longer. Just keep going with the damn story.”
         “Ok” Joseph answered as if defeated.
11411111111111111.title: Frog Drugs

114111111111111111.content:
“While skimming through the chapter on reptiles, I came upon the subsection on snakes. Oh boy. I practically threw that book to the ground and screamed like a girl at the sight of those scaly heads. It took me a little while to recover, but I managed. I found the place where I left off and immediately folded the page over before continuing.” Laughing to himself “And I thought the nightmares were bad.
         “Next came the birds. While the beautiful and bizarre fouls of Section Four were pretty to look at, I was growing ever more fretful at the increasing frequency of the unreadable glyphs. It seemed that the closer I came to the end of the guide, the more they seemed to creep up on me. The other unnerving detail of this section was the final entry depicting a very large bird. The five foot Kresht had brownish green feathers for camouflage, could reach speeds that surpassed the any other land creature thus far. It could certainly give you a run for your money. And it had a sharp beak for rending the flesh from its prey.
         “Reading that, I was so freaked out I had to put the book down for a sec and take a look around. When I was satisfied by the unbothered stir of the forest and the still resting Gimp, I pulled my spear in a bit closer and uneasily resumed reading to Section Five. Looking back, I guess I failed to consider the distant warning cry of the zimzim; easily the brightest and loudest bird in all Naxia.
         “It was almost laughable that something as dreadful as the kresht could be followed up by the most adorable little mouse anyone had ever seen. At the time, I thought it was some kind of positive omen for the rest of the volume. Or rather, I tried to think of it that way. As I read through the remaining creatures, a sense of unease was growing in my gut, almost like I could feel time was running out.
114111111111111111.title: Reptiles and Birds and Mammals. Oh My!

1141111111111111111.content:
“My pace quickened as I made my way through a series of large rodents, pigs, Gimp, a bison, deer, and many others. I remember thinking to myself: Over nine tenths through this damn book and still no sign of humans. I started to think that the book was teasing me and I still stand by that.
         “What followed was a trio of predators of ever increasing size that made my heart run a marathon. The first resembled a gralder, except this one was twice as large and had wings. Next came the Droms; aka, those giant dogs that I saved you from. The third and final beast was some manner of big cat with long fangs extending below the roof of its mouth. My heart might have exploded out of my chest were it not for the suspiciously glaring fact that all of these large predators were situated in and around Naxia’s Teeth, all the way at the opposite end of the map.”
         Joseph paused and looked up for a moment. “In fact, almost all of the larger animals seemed to make their home in the top two thirds of the map; a most puzzling phenomenon that I couldn’t help but ponder. It’s almost like whomever or whatever dropped me off here did so in the least threatening part of the forest.” Looking back down at Felecia, “I know you’ve thought the same thing more than once.”
         It took a moment for Felecia to answer. “Yes I have, but only in reference to myself. Unlike you who, by your own statement, was dropped off in the ‘least threatening part of the forest’; I was left to fend for myself within Naxia’s Teeth, the most dangerous region in the land. That was over ten years ago.”
         “You’ve told me. In fact, didn’t you say that it was ten years precisely as of three months ago; as in the day I awoke?”
         Felecia glared at her questioner. “Just shut up and get on with the story.”
         “Fine then, only two animals left anyway.”
1141111111111111111.title: Rising Anxiety

11411111111111111111.content:
“Once I turned the page, I was immediately stunned by the most startling picture yet. It was a picture of me. Me! But it wasn’t me, not really. The man in the picture was almost ten years older. He wore thick fur garments that vaguely resembled the fur of the big cat with the saber teeth. His body was hunched over as he stalked through the forest. In his right hand he gripped a spear with some kind of stone tip tied to the end. The hair on his face and head was surprisingly trim, especially in comparison to these mats.” Joseph tilted his head and stroked his hair so that Felecia could see his rat’s nest.
         “Over half of the descriptions in the entry were written in the unreadable glyphs. As time went on, I grew angrier and angrier at every occurrence of the glyphs. Again I thought that the damn book was mocking me by denying what were and still may be its most crucial facts? There was even a big black block where a picture should have been. What’s up with that?” Joseph exhaled with heavy frustration. “I went over the remaining tidbits of useless facts that littered the section, their meaning managing to elude him.
         “I guess I was too preoccupied with what the final entry might hold. My imagination raced to guess what it might be. The result of this was an unholy collage of spikes, teeth, tentacles, and claws. I desperately wanted to turn the page in order to alleviate my self-torment, but my hand refused to cooperate. It was shaking like chattering teeth I was so nervous.
         “I kept following the words, even the unreadable ones, until at last I found myself at the end of the final page on me. There was no turning back now.”
11411111111111111111.title: Vision of The Future

114111111111111111111.content:
“The first thing I saw was the picture. I was certainly relieved that the creature I saw didn’t remotely resemble the abomination I was expecting. Standing majestically atop a large stone at the border of Naxia’s Teeth, a great lilac purple cat gazed out upon her territory.

“In an effort to ignore the anxiety from my thunderous heartbeat, I started back through the guide. If I remember correctly, it described the creature as an Utek, or Panthera Sapien. It also said that this giant cat was more physically powerful than any human on record with the exception of three, and then came more glyphs. Wonder who they might have been.”

Felecia gave a light chuckle at his words. Joseph decided not to push the subject.

“In-between the glyphs were all kinds of useless footnotes; a lot of which included it enormous size and weight. Apparently an Utek can stand about 3.5 meters tall with its head fully raised. Go figure, huh.

“Others talked about the fact that since the Utek seemed like such a freakishly powerful super predator that it probably originates somewhere other than Naxia. What do ya think of that?”

Felecia had been looking away from Joseph ever since he started this subject. Clearly it was making her uncomfortable.

“I remember thinking to myself, it’s like the damn books deliberately avoiding whether or not this “super predator” eats humans. I was so wrapped up in my reading that I failed to notice the once distant warning cries of the birds grow ever closer before finally falling silent.”

At last he had regained Felecia’s interest.
114111111111111111111.title: Panthera Sapien

1141111111111111111111.content:
“The tension slowly dissipated from my body as I turned to the very last page. I thought, it’s the last page. What else was there? Low and behold all remaining text had been replaced with the glyphs. But I didn’t notice this until much later. My attention was focused on the second appearance of a second picture in a single entry. Damn that thing was freaky.

“It seemed like an unremarkable sketch of some kind of dark rock partially hidden behind layers of a familiar batch of long grass. After pondering this for a few seconds, I finally realized where I had seen it before and turned back to the Volume on plants. I skimmed through the pages a bit before finally finding it. It was little more than a photo of a common kind of grass called Emel. I was holding the pages with his left thumb and forefinger so I could hold my place. I flipped back and forth between them in an effort to compare the two images.

“The image in the plant Volume, like every other picture in the guide, was a photograph. While the Volume Five version was the one and only sketch, and a pretty well drawn sketch at that. As I continued to stare at the sketch trying to deduce its purpose, I gradually became aware of two small yellow blotches on the rock. Pulling the book closer, the blotches becoming ever clearer, I at last he noticed their symmetric positions and shapes. As I drew the book ever closer to my face, I was able to make out lines that seemed to take the shape of a nose. From there an image of a face was formed, followed soon after by teeth, a lower jaw and a crouching body. But always I kept going back to those yellow hypnotic cat eyes.” Joseph’s heart continued to race just as it had done that very day.

“A sudden nearby rustle caused me to jump. I fumbled to recapture the loose book, but to no avail. Turning to the source of the sound, I saw that Gimp had woken from her nap. She was sitting up, her ears perked, fur standing on end, and eyes glued somewhere off in front of her and I. As I stared at her, at last it dawned on me that the forest was dead silent. Not a chirp, squawk, or squeak for miles.

“Turning my head to face the same direction as Gimp, I immediately noticed a small rustle in a patch of Emel not 30 meters in front of me. And in that Emel were those same cold yellow eyes as depicted in the sketch.”
1141111111111111111111.title: A Second Illusion

11411111111111111111111.content:
“You really were scared, weren’t you.” Felecia insinuated.
         After his most recent ordeal, Joseph felt strong enough to look her in the eye and answer. “Of course I was.” He said accusingly. “For Gods’ sake I was practically in the middle of a clearing with an unknown predator staring right at me! How the hell would you have felt?”
         Felecia crunched her brow. “I felt scared. If you recall, I was no older than you are now when I first woke up in this place. My early years were filled with running, escaping, and glares from hungry predators. It wasn’t until much later that I became strong enough not to run.”
         Joseph calmed down and continued. “It didn’t take a genius to figure out what I was looking at. But I wasn’t exactly in a thinking state of mind. Those eyes… it felt like they were swallowing me alive. I might have stayed lost in those eyes if it weren’t for Gimp. And you’ll never guess what she did,” Joseph said sarcastically.
         “Oh I don’t know” Felecia answered acerbically with a false smile. “Did she do the only intelligent thing and run away?”
         “Yeah” Joseph exhaled. “I heard a rustle from where she was lying which broke me out of that trance. It took me a bit but the sound of claws scraping against wood forced me to look up. The bitch was half way up the damn tree by then. Course, in her position, guess I would’ a done the same.
         “I quickly faced forward again to see if the Utek had come any closer. It hadn’t. It just stayed in the long grass in what I assume was a crouching position, ready to spring up and pounce on me in a second. Fortunately, I knew better than to get myself trapped in its eyes again. I glanced down hastily and immediately remembered the spear.
         “The gears started winding in my head. The Utek outmatched me in strength, speed, and size, but there was a chance that I had a superior intellect. I could use my small size and low center of gravity to my advantage. If I could manage to get the spear in just the right position, then it might be possible to use the beast’s own momentum against it; essentially I would make the Utek impale itself. It wasn’t much of a plan, but I knew that it was my only chance.
         “Placing my hand just over the spear, I looked back up and faced the Utek. I guess my expression gave away the fact that I had a plan, because it was then that the Utek decided to show herself. It wasn’t her full height mind you, but the grass she stood in, the grass that could conceal my stomach, barely brushed her elbows. Disregarding this I grasped the spear in my hand and got to my feet. I turned backwards for all of a full second before I found a suitable notch in the tree in which I could use as leverage for the spear. As I turned to face forward again, a short, heavy, warm gust hit my face. A dark fuzzy wall eclipsed my view as the air around me suddenly reeked of fresh animal carcasses. And when I looked up, all I could see was that giant maw surrounded by teeth.”
11411111111111111111111.title: Something in the Long Grass

114111111111111111111111.content:
“If I recall correctly” Felecia interjected with a snicker, “I believe that you voided your bowels at that point.”
         “You recall wrong. Although I was close.” The two shared a brief laugh together before Joseph resumed his tale. “My eyes slowly fell from that great maw. The beast’s body covered in that dark violet, almost black fur. Finally I saw my spear. The tip was barely an inch away from her fur, and I’d guess two inches from her skin. It must have been about here,” Joseph said while pressing against the soft gap at the front of his collar bone, “just below the voice box, where the neck meets the torso. In theory, it should count as a weak spot on most creatures.
         “I knew I had her,” Joseph said, recalling his racing heartbeat and tensed muscles. “I knew we were at a stale mate. If she made the slightest move then I’d un-lodge the spear’s base and pierce her windpipe. She’d probably have strength enough to give me a good swipe and take my head off before she died, but there was no way she’d be able to survive a wound like that.
         “That’s when I looked back up, past the teeth, into the beast’s eyes. I looked for any sign of fear or hesitation; anything that might indicate that we could both walk away from this. I might as well have been trying to spot birds under the dirt. I don’t want to say they were empty, but they were deep; as deep as the deepest sea and just as full.”
         “What’s a sea?” Felecia interrupted. “You were on a roll there and I’m sorry to interrupt, but I’ve never heard that term before.”
         Naturally, Joseph was upset that his chain of thought had been broken, but that didn’t make her question any less valid. Once he began thinking deeper into what he said and how he had said it, he gave silent gratitude to the gods that the light was dim enough to hide his blushing cheeks. After pondering for a few seconds, finding the best combination of words, Joseph was satisfied that he could give an adequate answer.
114111111111111111111111.title: The Utek

1141111111111111111111111.content:
Felecia gave a frustrated glare at Joseph’s answer. “What do you mean you don’t know?”
         “Just what I said,” Joseph shrugged his shoulders.
         “Bloody typical.” The aggravated Felecia groaned. “You go and use a beautiful metaphor like that and don’t even know what it means. Pathetic.”
         “Hold on there,” Joseph held out his hand and got to his feet. “I think I might have read it in the Guide, why don’t I just take a look?”
         “This only strengthens my point.” Felecia called out as Joseph walked away. “You seem to remember everything else about your life and that book, but the one thing I want to know is the one thing you can’t offer.”
         Joseph exhaled heavily. “I can’t be expected to remember ever single freaking thing. Besides, what’s got you so worked up about this one word?” He asked hoping to trap Felecia and force her to change the subject instead of him.
         Felecia held her mouth shut for a second while she processed the question. “I just want to know what ‘sea’ means so that I can keep up with the story, that’s all.” She insisted.
         “Are you sure that’s it?” Joseph inquired with mock enthusiasm. Joseph knew it was a dangerous gamble to pressure her, but he was confident that Felecia would blink before him. He gained a further confidence boost
         “I guess,” she mumbled, “it would be nice to know the context of what you said. I mean, is a sea really that deep and full? And besides” she whimpered, pushing her bottom lip out, “I wanted to know.”
         Joseph cursed Felecia. He knew what she wanted to ask but wouldn’t. After finally finding the section in the book that talks about the sea, the only answer he could give to the unasked question was ‘yes’.
         “Yes.” Joseph responded, turning around to face Felecia. “Eyes as deep and full as the sea does mean beautiful.” He looked down at the open pages of the book as he walked back to his place at her side. “The passage goes on and on about how the sea sparkles. ‘Billions of fish in millions of colors can make the sea indistinguishable from a living rainbow.’ Shame there aren’t any in Naxia. Guess I’ll just have to make do with something just as good. “Joseph smiled. He knew that he had blinked first, but wasn’t too sore about his loss.
1141111111111111111111111.title: The Beauty of the Sea

12131.title: Shrink

121312.content: So who is our lucky born tiny? How about Dipper?
121312.title: Gravity Falls Born Shrunk

1213121.content:
(Prelude: Dipper is a minizora. They're people born 1 in a million and can be 3 to 5 inches tall. They're durable enough to be stepped on and even survive stomach acid, but not invincible. Based on the story by https://www.writing.com/main/interactive...)

Dipper had had an eventful last few hours to say the least. After being dropped off by their folks in this tourist trap town, he and his sister Mabel had a bit of an incident. And by incident, he’s obviously referring to Mabel being kidnapped and almost forced into marriage with 1,000 gnomes, followed by an epic chase in a golf cart from a composite gnome monster, and ending with the defeat of said monster with a leaf blower. However, now that the adrenaline had fallen and they were up in the attic for the evening, Dipper took greater interest with his initial big discovery: a mysterious journal with a six fingered hand on the cover. Of particular interest to the three inch tall boy was that the book was sized to minizora like himself.

“What’ch’ya readin’ there, bro-bro?” asked Mabel. The regular sized twelve year old was hanging upside down off the edge of her bed. She wore her usual purple sleeping sweater as her feet kicked idly in the air.

“The journal about the mysteries of Gravity Falls,” Dipper explained. “You know, the one I showed you a few hours ago back when I thought the gnomes were actually a zombie.”

Mabel gave a snorting laugh. “Yeah. Great job being the smart twin. Can’t even tell the difference between gnomes and zombies.”

Dipper narrowed his eyes on his sister. “Oh yeah? Well you followed a strange guy you’d only just met out into the woods where anything could have happened! Honestly, it turning out to be gnomes was pretty lucky on your end.”

“Hey, it’s not my fault! I thought he was a vampire.”

“And that makes it better?”

Mabel folded her arms and turned away in a huff, still upside-down. “I won’t even dignify that with a response.”

“He’s been out in the sun all day wearing only a hoodie,” reminded Dipper.

“He could be using super vampire sunblock. You don’t know,” Mabel whined.

“Mabel, that makes literally no sense.”

“Sure it does. In fact, I know how to settle this. You’ve got a journal full of weird stuff, right? Go ahead and check.”

Dipper gave a soft chuckle as he flipped through the pages. “You know, that was a lot more mature than what I was expecting from you.”

“What is that supposed to mean? I’m super mature! I’m the most maturest mature person to ever… mature! Also I’m a girl, and everyone knows girls mature faster than boys,” she finished with a dignified huff.

Dipper rolled his eyes. “Riiight. Mabel is sooo mature. She shops for teddy bear undies in the big girl isle.”

Cheeks flushed, Mabel’s hands shot down (relative to her perspective) to cover her sweater over her unmentionables. “You saw nothing!”

“Yeah, yeah,” Dipper said with a dismissive wave. “You and your… wait a minute.” He stopped flipping through pages and brought the book up to his face. “I found it! The section on vampires.”

“Show me!” Mabel tried to stand, but only managed to flip onto her face with a thud. “Ow. Ugh. Just read it to me.”

“Huh. Well I’ll be. It says here that vampires do sometimes use a super sunblock.”

“Ah ha!” Mabel shot a fist up in triumph.

“Buuut,” Dipper continued, “it’s made of ingredients considered repugnant by vampires. If a vampire were actually using the stuff, they’d also have to wear nose plugs so they don’t gag.”

Mabel’s arm fell limp. “Ah poo.” Once she grew bored of lying on the floor, Mabel sat up and walked across the room to the side of Dipper’s regular sized bed and planted her chin on the sheets. She looked down at him with curious and thoughtful eyes.

“Mabel,” Dipper said warily as the big face loomed over him. “What’s that look for?”

“Oh nothing. Just thinking how lucky I am to have a little,” she snickered, “brother like you.”

“Oh ha-ha.”

“I mean it. You’re so tiny, but you still came after me even when you thought I was about to be eaten by a zombie. You also drove a golf cart like a total pro. How’d you do that again?”

“Specially modified for minizora drivers,” Dipper explained, trying to focus on his reading. Now that he’d started, there were just so many interesting factoids about vampires he’d never considered before. “Besides, you’d have done the same for me.”

“Well duh! But that’s different. You were in, like, way more danger than me back there. What if one of those creepy gnomes stepped on you?”

“I’ve been stepped on before. Not that big a deal,” Dipper explained dismissively. “Also, I wasn’t the target for what I assume to have been an attempted gang bang by said creepy gnomes.”

Mabel pouted cutely. “You’re making it really hard to give a heartfelt thank you for saving my life, you know. You put your life on the line for me when you didn’t have to, and that means a lot.”

Dipper finally closed the book. “Actually, I did have to.”

“Huh?”

“It’s like when someone’s driving and a rabbit runs out in the middle of the road.
